  From: Maciej Zawadzki [mailto:mbz@...]

  Subject: [junit] Dependencies between tests and test ordering


  Hello,

  I'm pretty new to the JUnit tool and am not yet completely familiar with
  its idiosyncrasies.  I have a question about how best to apply JUnit to
  solve my particular testing need.

  Basically I have a class (lets say Fruit.class) that is being mapped to
  a database via an O/R  tool.  I would like to test this this mapping.
  So I have a TestCase called FruitCRUDTestCase.  In my test case I have
  test methods such as testCreate(), testRestore(), testUpdate(), and
  testDelete().  Now, when writing these kind of tests before JUnit, I
  could make the tests dependent on each other.  For example, if the
  testCreate() method created an object, I could store a reference to it
  in an instance attribute and access again from the other test methods
  (testRestore() for example).  To my understanding, this does not seem to
  be easily doable when using JUnit.  I can create a TestSuite that will
  execute each of my test methods, I can even create an OrderedTestSuite
  (from gsbase) that will execute my test methods in the order that I
  specify, but each test method will be executed within its own instance
  of TestCase so I can not use instance attributes to make data accessible
  between test methods.  Is there something that I am missing?

  Now I know that I can make the test methods completely independent to
  get around this problem, but why?

  I think because it fits the philosophy of writing many small independent
unit tests methods. Each one showing a clear self-documenting simple
example.

  The junit framework forces you into that way of working.

  Later on, it makes refactoring more easy (no side effects, non unclear
dependencies).

  Making the test methods independent
  would require duplicating effort since the testRestore() method would
  have to create an object first (basically duplicate what is already
  being done in testCreate()).

  OK, but you can reduce the code effort by using static utilities
  (see for example the article on the web about the "ObjectMother pattern",
Thoughworks).

  Maybe, it is not the fastest way in terms of performance, but you gain
several
  other advantages (flexibility, clarity, maintainability, pleasure,...).

  Adelbert Groebbens

  Basically I am looking for input before I write something myself. Maybe
  someone has dealt with this problem before (I'm sure some has -- it's
  not that unique of a problem).  If so, please let me know how you've
  solved this.  I am willing to write a simple extension that will support
  the type of behavior that I've described, but maybe there is a better
  way of doing things.

  Thanks,

  --Maciej
